title: CTRL0000086315 - Transcribed Interview of Ruby Freeman, (May 31, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held in Room 4480, O'Neill House Office
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
MICHAELJ. GOTTLIEB, PARTNER, WILLKIE FARR & GALLAGHER LLP
ELEANOR WALKER, ASSOCIATE, WILLKIE FARR & GALLAGHER LLP
MERYL GOVERNSKI, ASSOCIATE, WILLKIE FARR & GALLAGHER LLP
JOHN TYLER KNOBLETT, ASSOCIATE, WILLKIE FARR & GALLAGHER LLP
DAVID A. SCHULZ, SENIOR COUNSEL, BALLARD SPAHR
This is a transcribed interview of Ruby Freeman,
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd like to ask the witness to please state your full name and spell
your last name for the record.
My name is Ruby Jewel Freeman.
the spelling of the last name is F-r-e-e-m-a-n.
And, counsel for Ms. Freeman, could you please identify yourselves for the
Meryl Governski, with Willkie Farr & Gallagher.
Michael Gottlieb, with Willkie Farr & Gallagher.
John Tyler Knoblett, for Willkie Farr & Gallagher.
Are you able to hear us?
And I think we have some co-counsel here participating virtually.
This is Rachel Goodman, with Protect Democracy.
And it looks like -- is there someone else?
This is Eleanor Walker, with Willkie Farr & Gallagher.
So thank you all for being here this afternoon.
I will go over some preliminaries
So, as I mentioned before we went on the record, this is going to be a staff-led
to keep track, and they will hopefully come in and out if they are able to join us.
And if any of them choose while they are here to ask questions,
We probably won't announce when they leave because it can be hard
And I am joined in the room today by my colleague
, professional staff member for the committee.
And before we begin, Ms. Freeman, I'd just like to go over some ground rules for
patience as I go through them.
We will do our best to announce their arrival for the record and
Again, as I said off the record, my name is
Members of the select committee may join us.
They're the same rules we give to everyone.
So there are official reporters here.
They are going to be creating a transcript of
As I mentioned before, we are recording this through the video
camera here, but the official record of the interview is the transcript that our official
transcript and suggest any corrections before it's finalized.
You and your attorneys will have an opportunity to review the
And because we're creating the official record in the transcript, we'll ask that you
please wait until our questions are finished before you start talking, and I will similarly try
my best not to start a new question before you've been able to answer your own, just so
that the record is as clear as possible.
We'll also ask that you give verbal responses to our questions as opposed to a
shaking head or nodding head, because the reporters can only record a verbal response.
I also say, you know, we appreciate your appearance here voluntarily, and we're
pleased to be able to meet with you in person.
So thank you for making the trip up here
Although today's interview is not under oath like a deposition would be, I do want
to remind you, as we remind all of our witnesses, that it is unlawful to deliberately
So, again, it's really important that you understand our questions and are able to
answer them to the best of your ability today.
So, if anything I ask you is unclear or if
you need any clarification, please don't hesitate to ask, and I'd be happy to rephrase.
have been known to ask an unclear question every once in a while, so please don't
And, again, we ask that you respond only to your ability to do so truthfully.
you don't know the answer to a question, please say that, or if you don't recall, please
just tell us that that's the case.
And, logistically, we are happy to take any breaks that you need during our time
I don't want to -- we are going to try not to keep you here overly long.
you need any breaks, either to go outside, have a bathroom break, get something to
drink, or if you need to consult with your attorneys, please just let us know and we're
other room we have available if you'd like to have a longer conversation.
You could have a brief sidebar in here, or we can take you back to the
So any questions about all of those throat-clearing -- the preliminaries here?
Nothing to address, and no questions.
Ms. Freeman, I understand that you've prepared something, a statement that
you'd like to share with us.
Well, thank you for inviting me here to tell me story.
You should not know me or my name.
this is not the way it was supposed to be.
I've always believed it when God says that he'll make your name great, but
I could've never imagined the events that
For my entire professional life, I was Lady Ruby.
where I was born and lived my whole life knew me as Lady Ruby.
business around that name, La Ruby's Unique Treasures, a pop-up shop catering to ladies
I wore a shirt that proudly proclaimed that I was and I am Lady Ruby.
had that shirt in every color.
since, and I'll never wear it again.
I wore that shirt on election day 2020.
Now I won't even introduce myself by my name anymore.
bump into someone I know in the grocery store who says my name.
always concerned of who is around me.
I get nervous when I have to give my name for food orders.
I've lost my name, and I've lost my reputation.
I've lost my sense of security -- all
because a group of people, starting with Number 45 and his ally Rudy Giuliani, decided to
scapegoat me and my daughter, Shaye, to push their own lies about how the Presidential
Some of his supporters and right-wing media organizations repeated those lies
They accused me of committing crimes, of helping to steal the election.
They accused me of hiding ballots in suitcases, of counting ballots multiple times, of
passing around some kind of flash drive by hacking machines that they said were being
What is true is that I signed up as an election worker because I believe in our
Not one single piece of it.
career has been devoted to making sure that Fulton County elections are fair and that
I signed up to support my daughter, Shaye, whose entire professional
I taught my daughter that if you are going to something, you do it right, and you
It made me proud to watch her succeed in a profession that she loved.
Shaye was dedicated to her job and making sure that it was
We showed up to work on election night, proud to be playing a small role in
us, like countless other election workers, we don't show up to help any candidate or
from their work or school, who travel for miles and stand in line for hours to have their
That's the thing that people who attack us refuse to accept:
We show up to help the voters -- the millions of voters who take time off
Our work honors those voters, those who fought and sacrificed to make sure that
all people have the right to vote in America.
about democracy, fairness, and respect for our fellow citizens.
Doing this work is not about politics; it is
But because some people didn't like the outcome of the fair and accurate election
in Fulton County, they decided to attack Shaye and me by name and by picture.
received hundreds of racist, threatening, horrible calls and messages that I do not even
I had to move out of my house because the FBI said it wasn't safe.
came by my home the week of January 6th.
One person told me I had 48 hours to give
them some sort of statement to avoid going to jail -- to admit to something I never did.
They tried to force their way into my mom's house to do a citizens' arrest on
Friends and members of my community were afraid to even be
associated with me because they didn't want to get caught up in the harassment.
There is nowhere I feel safe -- nowhere.
Do you know how it feels to have the President of the United States to target you?
The President of the United States is supposed to represent every American, not to target
American citizen who stood up to help Fulton County run an election in the middle of the
But he targeted me, Lady Ruby, a small-business owner, a mother, a proud
He said my name 18 times -- 18 times -- to the Georgia secretary of state,
The President of the United States made up lies about two ordinary Americans for
who repeat whatever they say spoon fed us as enemies and villains to their mob.
said we were like drug dealers passing out ballots.
as a prop in the "big lie."
Then he and he allies like Rudy Giuliani and those in the media
States eggs on a mob, that mob will come.
threats, their racism, and their hats.
And, lo and behold, when someone as powerful as the President of the United
They came for us with their cruelty, their
Number 45 and his crew have destroyed our lives.
So I won't call Number 45 by
He and his allies took my name, so I won't utter his.
This is about truth and decency.
more than myself and my daughter.
I hope that by me telling my story that you all can
help prevent the next Ruby becoming a target, the next Shaye.
The people need to be held accountable.
Congress needs to protect our election workers.
It needs to take steps to
prevent the spread of lies that threaten our democracy.
I am just one name, one
reputation, one life devastated by disinformation, but there are so many more, and there
will be even more if things don't change.
Throughout all of this, I have been blessed by my family, friends, and my faith.
And despite it all, I've never questioned my faith, and I still do not.
because I'm reminded in the Word that faith is the substance of things hoped for and the
But faith alone is not enough to save our country and democracy.
My faith is all I have,
This requires action and change to ensure that what happened to us will
And in order to get something different, you have to do something
I'm not sure that I should continue with any
questioning because there's not very much that I can add to that.
So thank you very much for being here.
Thank you for sharing those thoughts.
I know this has all been very difficult, has been hugely difficult for you.
light of that, thank you for sharing it, and thank you for your patience as we have a
I just want to state, before we go into some of the, you know, history here and
what you've gone through, that we really appreciate for all of the reasons that you just
identified, because, on behalf of the select committee, I know that the members of the
committee feel that what happened to you and to your daughter is not only wrong and
unjust but they hope that our work here can have something, you know, positive to do to
make sure that it doesn't happen again.
I also just want to say that our hope today is to be able to get as much of your
story to be a part of our record and our work here as possible, but we don't want to make
what is a difficult circumstance for you any harder.
So, if there are, sort of, some areas here that we're going to talk about today that
are particularly sensitive or difficult for you to relive, I hope that you'll let me know that,
and we can find a way to work around it, because I don't want to make this any more
So thank you in advance for your patience with my questions, and please let me
know if there's anything that you want to take off the record.
I would love to just rewind a little bit and talk a bit more about your personal
So, Ms. Freeman, thank you very much again for those comments.
background before we get into the fact of what happened around the November 2020
So where are you from originally?
Have you lived in Georgia your whole life?
I have lived in Georgia my entire life.
I went to secretarial school, my educational
Went to secretarial school, and I -- yeah.
And I know you mentioned in your opening, your statement there, that you
-- that you started your own pop-up boutique.
I started out then when the Braves went to the World Series, from the
And later I did the Olympics.
Can you tell us a little bit
How long have you -- or, when did you first start your company?
I first started my company in 1987.
I was a street vendor for Atlanta-Fulton
I was the first one to start taking
We had the big black bag phones then.
So a lot of authentic merchandise, mainly, and so I was always known as "the
Neiman Marcus lady" that the merchandise just like inside.
and then once it got to be just kind of -- well, everybody sold Braves merchandise then, so
And I went back to working Fulton County, and I saw vendors downstairs.
was like, wow, what are they doing?
that they were selling purses and stuff.
it's just time to change gears.
And I did that for a while,
What are they doing down there?
And I heard a voice that told me, it's not over,
So I started selling merchandise for the boutique.
then moved on to jewelry, and then I sell clothes.
And I started off with purses,
So I sell unique ladies accessories and
I just wanted to note, we had somebody else in the waiting
Is that another counsel for your team?
Well, if he reappears, we'll know who he is.
So, Ms. Freeman, if you could tell us -- first of all, had you ever
worked on the tabulation process in an election before 2020?
I worked the election for President Obama, the first one.
that, for Fulton County Registration and Elections.
And so how did you come to be employed by Fulton County for the 2020 election?
I started out with Fulton County years ago, and then I went to do temporary
So that's how I got there.
And I think you mentioned that your daughter has been -- as reflected in public
reporting, your daughter had been employed with the Fulton County Registration and
Elections Department for some time at that point.
Yes, she was employed with Fulton County Voters Registration and Elections.
So why don't you tell us a little bit in your own words about your experience of
work on election day, on November 3, 2020.
Well, we went in on election day 2020 as a normal workday to count the
And that's what we did; we counted ballots.
It's a long -- it was a long day?
It was a very long day.
Yeah, even in a normal election, but especially -- it's my understanding from
our work that, because there were so many more absentee ballots and mail-in ballots in
2020, that that further added to the burden for election workers on election day.
And that was what we were doing at the State Farm Arena; we were
there to count the absentee ballots.
And we don't need to go into too much technical detail, but, generally speaking,
what were your responsibilities at State Farm Arena in the tabulation process?
My responsibility for that day was to be an opener, which was to open the
ballots after they had been cut, just to open the ballots from the precincts to make sure
that everything added up, the ballots and the envelopes they came in, just to make sure
Did you work before election day also, or was your work for
Fulton County in 2020 limited to election day only?
I started working with Fulton County Voters Registration and Elections as a
They had a runoff, so I worked there then.
And then I left because that was over, and they called us back when it was time to
really get busy for the election.
So I went to the government center and I worked there.
And then when it was close to the time, because of my work ethics, they called me
to come and work with the -- at State Farm for the finishing part of it.
And so it's my understanding, especially because of how many absentee ballots
were submitted in the 2020 election, that the counting continued after election day on
Well, you always have the provisionals.
So, yes, that is correct; you have
And did you continue to work for the Fulton County Registration
Yes, I did, at the State Farm.
I worked there until that was over with.
we worked at State Farm to do the -- the other ballots.
And do you remember about how many days total after the
election you continued to work at State Farm Arena?
After the election, really we just did cleanup work.
went back to the Fulton County Government Center.
So, during the process, you know, I would expect that the day, on election day,
while long and hard work, went as you expected.
It went long like I expected, because I had experienced it
with President Oba ma's election, to know that the last ballots would come in would be
from Milton, Georgia, and Johns Creek, which is farther off.
their -- the time was still the same, but then they had to get everything together and back
up to send to the State Farm Arena, for those ballots to be counted, because people were
So at what point after your work on tabulating the ballots or during it did you start
to realize that there was something amiss, that there was, you know, attention brought
to you for the first time?
Yeah, it wasn't a very well phrased question, so apologies for that.
I'm basically wondering, when did you first realize that this problem that,
you know, was caused for you here -- when did you first realize that?
December the 3rd was when I first realized.
And is that -- that's the date that Rudy Giuliani and several
associates appeared at a hearing of the Georgia State Senate.
So how did you first learn of it?
I first learned about what all was going on that night, the December the 3rd,
I've heard that that was the date that he did what he did.
on the phone with a girlfriend.
friend on Facebook, and she began to talk about stuff.
And I had -- someone wanted me to accept them as a
So I asked my girlfriend, I said,
She looked in Messenger, and she said, "Yeah, she's a real person.
So I did not accept her as a friend, but I responded to her message.
saying that she wanted to interview me.
And I'm like, interview me for what?
And that's when it all got started.
So did you speak to the reporter or to the friend?
I was on the phone with the friend, but I never talked with the reporter,
because after that point -- first, I said yes, you know, because I don't know what's going
I didn't have an attorney or a lawyer at that time.
And then after my phone just started blowing up all night and that next morning
and -- I notified her and I said, "I think I need an attorney.
I won't be able to talk to
And she said, "Yes, you do, but if you want to talk, then let me know."
So when you first -- you know, your friend started mentioning this to you and you
realized that the reporter wanted to talk to you, what did you understand to have caused
Did you learn about the video that they played during the hearing?
No, I didn't know about the video at that moment.
moment was they said that I was stealing ballots, I was trying to steal ballots for President
And what did you think when you first --
I did not -- I did not understand anything.
I didn't -- I didn't know what they
I just knew it sound like something serious.
So that next morning I left and I went to -- because it was Fulton County.
had worked with Fulton County Police Department, so I was like, I need to go to Fulton
County Police Department and let them know.
So I went to -- I called Voters Registration and Elections, I was letting them know
and so I went to their office.
And they immediately said that they wanted to talk to me,
And then I went to the police department.
And they got my phone, and it was
just blowing up, and people were talking and cursing, and they were gonna -- you know,
So she handled a lot of the calls, you know, and that's how that got
So I didn't realize that people got your phone number so quickly
after that video was posted on -- or aired on December 3rd.
calls and text messages started arriving?
So, after you went to talk with folks at the Registration and Elections Department
And you said there was a video.
I did not know about the video at
So all I know is that the phone started blowing up about it.
I didn't even think how they got my phone number.
and then at the police department, what happened next?
What happened after I finished talking with the police department and
Voters Registration and Elections, I was then told that we had to come downtown to
meet with different departments that wanted to interview us to find out exactly what
happened each -- you know, those days.
And were those individuals associated the secretary of state's office --
-- who wanted to meet with you?
That was one of them, was the secretary of state.
And so they set up an appointment for us to
It was the secretary of state -- the ones we met with was the secretary
of state, it was the FBI, the GBI, the county manager's office, Fulton County manager's
Do you remember when that meeting took place?
No, not -- I don't know the exact date.
just kind of was, like, happening.
I just was trying to live at that point because --
So I didn't keep a record of what happened what day.
But it was probably within a day or two of when
I would say within the week.
So, within that timeframe when you met with the law enforcement and county
officials, tell me just generally, what do you remember about the meeting?
I don't remember the exact topics, but I know they were investigating,
like -- they were asking what happened that night, you know, with the ballots.
reporters, they were just asking a lot of different questions as to what happened that
we crossed every "t" and dotted every "i," whatever we did.
They were trying -- they were investigating to see if we did something wrong, if
And was your daughter, Ms. Moss, also interviewed at that time?
All the ones that were interviewed were the ones that was at the
Did you ever get interviewed again by any of those law enforcement or
government officials, or was it just that one time?
Anything else that sticks out in your memory about the process of going in and
It was just that one time.
I'm sure it was intimidating, with all of these various government
And it wasn't -- I wouldn't say it was intimidating, because I worked for the police
You know, I maintained the database for 911 for 8 years.
I shouldn't have suggested that, because I sense that you're not a woman
So what else -- what happened after that?
Well, let me ask you, at that
point, when you had the interview with the law enforcement officials, were you aware of
I did not look at a lot of stuff.
No, I wasn't aware of the video at that point.
I didn't listen to the news.
some people that would call me and tell me certain things or they would send me
different clips of something, you know, but I didn't get many of those.
I didn't want to know anything.
Did you later come to learn about this video that had been circulating?
Which video are you speaking of?
I was thinking of the one that was shown during the hearing.
understanding is that there was a hearing of a senate committee and a long video was
shown, and then there was a shorter clip that was kind of made and posted onto social
media and other places, including by Mr. Giuliani.
What did -- I don't know which one you're speaking of.
Which video are you speaking of?
So my understanding is that there was a short clip -- and we
could pull it up if that would be easier to look at -- but where Mayor Giuliani posted a
video that was, like, screens of a surveillance camera about ballot processing during the --
-- you know, election night at State Farm Arena.
I can somewhat recall that one, yes, ma'am.
I'm just wondering if you came to be familiar with it, and if so, you know,
how did you learn about this video that was circulating.
How did I learn about the video?
me to look on the VouTube.
What did you think when you saw it?
be, not what it actually was.
I thought it was -- it was horrible, it was
They felt that -- they made it to be what they wanted it to
Did you see any interviews or statements by -- well, let me rephrase.
I'm aware that individuals associated with or employed by the secretary of state's
office started speaking out very quickly after this to try to debunk the video, to provide
context and provide knowledge that what was being said about the video was not true.
Did you learn of any of those things around this time period in early December
I did hear that, you know -- after I heard about my name being mentioned 18
times by Number 45 and the secretary of state, I did hear a lot about that they said it was
be incorrect, that we did not steal the ballots, we did not have anything to do with
There was found -- after the recounts and the recounts, that they found it to
And I'm also aware that President Trump appeared in Georgia at the beginning
part of December -- I think it was around December 6th -- for a campaign rally in
connection with the Senate runoff, the next election that was going on in Georgia, and he
played a news clip that focused on this video.
Were you aware of this at the time when he did that?
When did you learn of it?
Ma'am, I did not follow the news.
interested in seeing it, because it was -- it was a horrible experience.
I wanted it all to go away, because it was all a big lie, and there was nothing I
I was just trying to find me an attorney.
When you did learn that the President had stopped the campaign rally to air this
news clip focusing on these lies, these allegations, how did that make you feel?
I don't even think I remember hearing about him and a campaign -- about
But it sounds like you certainly did hear about it when you had the phone call with
So tell me about the circumstances.
How did you learn about that
Just, I heard about it from just listening to the news.
Sometimes, every now and then, I would turn on the news just to hear something, or I
would put my name in Google or something, and it would bring up different things.
So what did you learn when you saw this call had taken place?
you find out that your name was mentioned during the phone call?
Yes, I found out my name was mentioned during that phone call, later.
So I know you discussed this a little bit in your statement, so --
-- thank you in advance for your patience as I go over this stuff a little bit
But tell me about, you know, sort of, how you learned about the President using
your name in that call and what the impact was for you.
Once again, I heard about it on the news.
I don't know how, whether it
was VouTube, Google, or if someone called me to tell me, I'm not really sure.
But the way that it made me feel was horrible.
of the United States is mentioning my name and saying to find some ballots.
you can just find -- all we need is -- however many they said.
And to mention my name over and over, I thought -- it was horrible.
You have nothing else to do other than to mention my name several times, over
And, at that point, it was almost a month or about a month after this lie, this
allegation, had first arisen, and as I think we were, you know, referring to earlier, there
were plenty of opportunities for the truth about what happened to have come out at that
Did that factor into your, sort of, interpretation, your understanding of what the
President was doing, the fact that it had already been proven to be a lie at that point?
At that point, it had been proven to be a lie, but he -- I felt that that wasn't
the threats and everything that I got, they was trying to say I committed a crime.
He still was trying to say that I committed a crime.
Did you learn -- did you ever learn about the President's speech on January 6th
Well, the President spoke from the Ellipse, which is the area in front of the
But included in his comments was a reference to the allegation about suitcases
And so I just wondered whether you became aware of the President including a
There was a large crowd, and he spoke to them at
remark about this lie that we've been discussing today in his speech on January 6th.
Well, I would like to talk with you a little bit more about the threats that you
received and the impact on you, but before I do that, I just want to see if there are any big
points in the story of, sort of, where this lie originated and where you, kind of, saw it
appear that you'd like to talk about.
I was not aware of him with the speech, January 6th,
Where did I see the lie appear?
I saw the lies appear in the -- like I said, it
was either Google or somebody called to tell me.
I did not want to live that over and over.
And if sometimes I would have people to tell me, I'd say, "I don't want to
I did not want to see it, because it was horrible lies, and
So I don't remember a lot of what happened
Don't send me an email, no text message, no nothing.
So let's talk a little bit more about the threats, as much as you are comfortable
So I know you've already told us that in the early December time period, right
You know, I didn't want anybody calling me to tell me
-- your phone started ringing and that you went to the police department.
What impact on your life did you experience after that
The impact that it had on my life?
I was afraid to go out.
It turned my whole life around.
I was afraid for people to call my name.
afraid to order food and somebody would ask, what's your name?
like, just standing there looking at them, you know, and then I would have to come up
Or if I was at the red light and somebody was staring, you know, it was like, I didn't
know why they were staring, why -- you know.
So I was always fearful, I was always afraid.
And I think you told us earlier in your statement, you remarked about a time
where you had to move out of your house.
I had to move out of my house.
So tell us a little bit more about that.
decide that you needed to leave your house for your own safety?
Around the week of January 6th, the FBI informed me that I needed to leave
And I left my home for safety around that time.
How long did you, you know, remain outside of your home
I stayed away from my home for approximately 2 months.
And it's obvious, but I have to say these things for the record --
-- so thanks for your patience, but how did that impact you?
I felt, you know, I can't believe -- I can't
believe this person has caused this much damage to me and my family, to have to leave
my home that I've lived there for 21 years.
neighbors watch out for me, you know, and I have to go and stay with somebody.
And, you know, I'm having to have my
And your conversation with the FBI about needing to leave your home for
your own safety, or perhaps recommending it, do you remember, was there a specific
threat that prompted that, or was it the accumulation of threats that you had received?
What prompted it was, it was getting ready to -- January 6th was about to
people would come into my home.
there, just in case something happened.
And they did not want me to be at home because of all the threats and
They didn't want me to be there, in fear of, you know, that
And I had a lot of that, so they didn't want me to be
I asked, how long am I gonna have to be out of my home?
Because it was just that bad, with people coming to my home and
threatening me and me getting mail, letters, and phone calls, you know, the phone calls
saying different stuff, like, "We know where you live.
a lot of different horrible, racist threats.
So, just generally speaking, what were the types of threats that you received?
know you've told us you got a lot of phone calls.
Were you also getting text messages or other types of email, electronic
The type threats that I received was email, text messages, Messenger,
Linked In, mail, people coming to the house.
And the types were -- they would say things like, "We know where you live, and
we're coming to get you, nigger."
